description: The Apple Certified Technical Coordinator certification is designed for anyone responsible for managing Apple computers and devices in a business environment. The exam is made up of content from the Support Essentials ACSP course, as well as content from the Server Essentials course which is covered in this show. Technologies covered include topics like network deployment, policy management, troubleshooting and using Open Directory for centralized user management.
name: ACSP macOS Server Essentials 10.11
subtitle: Apple Certified Support Professional

episodes.description: The Apple Certified Technical Coordinator certification is designed for anyone responsible for managing Apple computers and devices in a business environment. The exam is made up of content from the Support Essentials ACSP course, as well as content from the Server Essentials course which is covered in this show. Technologies covered include topics like network deployment, policy management, troubleshooting and using Open Directory for centralized user management.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Don walks us through how to install the Mac OS X Server App and provides a quick introduction to the various features inside the app. He also discusses the pre-requisites for installing as well as concerns when upgrading to a new version.
episodes.title: Installing OS X Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their discussion on how to install the Mac OS X Server App and provides a quick introduction to the various feature inside the app. They also discuss the pre-requisites for installing as well as concerns when upgrading to a new version.
episodes.title: Installing OS X Server Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Don walks us through the various name-lookup configurations for Mac OS X Server. He shows how to set the hostname for your server, how to create DNS zones and host records, and demonstrates setting up redundant DNS servers.
episodes.title: Domain Name System

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates the various ways that you can remotely manage a machine running the OS X Server App. He demonstrates SSH, screen sharing and remotely executing the Server App itself.
episodes.title: Remote Management

episodes.description: In this episode Don explains the various uses for certificates in Mac OS X Server. He demonstrates the self-signed certificates created by the Server App, as well as the process for securing publicly trusted certificates for use in Server App services
episodes.title: Certificates

episodes.description: In this episode, Don describes the three primary methods for monitoring an OS X Server to ensure it is online and healthy. He covers logging for past monitoring, statistics for real-time monitoring, and alerts for future monitoring.
episodes.title: Monitoring

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at how to keep Mac OS X Server up and running through common maintenance procedures. They demonstrate how to keep the base Mac OS X operating system up-to-date as well as the Server App. They will also explore the world of backups through Time Machine and how to ensure that service data on a separate drive can be included in the backup, and data that will be excluded during a backup operation
episodes.title: OS X Maintenance

topics.title: Configuring and Monitoring OS X Server

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don discuss user authentication and the different types of authentication. They explain topics like hashes, crypt passwords, password servers, Kerberos and the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol. They explore the different storage mechanisms like Crypt, Shadow and Open Directory.
episodes.title: User Authentication

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don introduce Open Directory for centralized identity and password management. They look at the basics  like the main components that make up the Open Directory and the initial setup. They talk about the roles that a server can play when setting up Open Directory.
episodes.title: Open Directory

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don take a look at user accounts and explore different user types, their characteristics and privileges inside of Mac OS X Server. They demonstrate how to create, manage and maintain a user accounts. They will guide the viewer through password policy creation as well as the effects of the policy on the end user experience.
episodes.title: User Accounts

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their discussion on user accounts and explore different user types, their characteristics and attributes. They demonstrate how to create groups within Open Directory as well as explain their administrative purposes. They explore using access control lists (ACLs) to control user access to services through the Server App. They wrap up by traveling into the world of troubleshooting user accounts.
episodes.title: User Accounts Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrates how to configure the Profile Manager to deploy configuration profiles to end user machines. They show you how to setup the Profile Manager for first use and the settings to accomplish this task.
episodes.title: Configuration Profiles

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their discussion on how to configure the Profile Manager to deploy configuration profiles to end user machines. They demonstrate some of the settings that can be configured including enrolling clients and creating configuration profiles.
episodes.title: Configuration Profiles Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their discussion on how to configure the Profile Manager to deploy configuration profiles to end user machines. They demonstrate some of the common settings within a configuration profile such as password settings, power management option, logon banners, WiFi profiles and more.
episodes.title: Configuration Profiles Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate using the Server App to create Share Points inside of Mac OS X. They discuss the various file sharing protocols, and examine the various permissions provided by POSIX and ACL based permission schemes.
episodes.title: Sharing Files

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate setting up a Caching Server inside of Mac OS X. They cover the basic considerations to be aware of when setting up a Caching Server. They discuss the type of content that can be cached including storage and supporting multiple subnet environments.
episodes.title: Caching Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate setting up a Software Update Service inside of Mac OS X. They discuss the considerations to understand when deploying the Software Update Service and well as approving, downloading and removing updates from the database.
episodes.title: Software Update

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don take a look at deploying OS X El Capitan images using NetInstall. They discuss the different types of NetInstall images. They demonstrate setting up the Server App and creating a basic NetInstall image.
episodes.title: Deployment with NetInstall

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don take a look at deploying OS X El Capitan images using NetRestore. They discuss customizing the reference Mac devices, creating the image and locating in on the network.
episodes.title: Deployment with NetRestore

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate image deployment with the NetInstall Server. They talk about deploying a default NetInstall image over the network. They will also take a look at deploying a customized NetRestore image to devices over the network as well as the some of the background processes that take place during the deployment.
episodes.title: Deploying an Image

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate setting up a Time Machine server for centralized management of Time Machine backups. They discuss the considerations that should be taken into account before setting up a Time Machine server. They take a look at configuring storage for the Time Machine Server.
episodes.title: Time Machine

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don discuss one of the most important services in networking today known as the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol. They demonstrate the common options that can be deployed to clients through DHCP like IP addresses, routers, DNS Servers and DNS search domains. They also examine setting up reservations for machines that need to keep the same IP addresses.
episodes.title: DHCP

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don examine setting up and configuring VPNs inside of OS X Server. They discuss the benefits of using virtual private networks, the protocols associated with tunneling like PPTP and L2TP. They demonstrate client-side configuration, connections and Configuration Profiles. They explain the TCP/IP ports that PPTP and L2TP as well as the encryption technologies used with these associated protocols.
episodes.title: Virtual Private Networks

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into the world of the OS X Web Server. They discuss the basic considerations that should be taken into account when setting up the web server. They take a look at port configuration, folder location, additional domains and various other options.
episodes.title: Basic Web Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don dive into the more of the advanced configuration that can be performed on OS X’s Web Server. They discuss topics range from Server Side Includes, htaccess files, CGI execution, to customizing error pages.
episodes.title: Advanced Web Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore using OS X Server to create Wiki Websites. They discuss the basics to consider when implementing Wiki Websites as well showing the viewer how to create a Wiki. They talk about Blogs and their characteristics as well as demonstrating how to create a blog.
episodes.title: Wiki Websites

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate using the Server App to setup and configure Mail Server. They explain the components in Mail Server such as PostFix, Dovecot, ClamAV and Spam Assassin. They discuss the common reason a company would host a Mail Server, the configurations and advanced functions.
episodes.title: Mail Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their demonstration of OS X Server’s Mail Server. They focus on the client-side setup using the Mail App. They explore the common protocols used to send and receive emails as well as the configurations needed to successfully use the email client.
episodes.title: Mail Server Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate setting up a centralized calendar system using Calendar inside the server app. The CalDAV and protocols like IMAP and POP that are used by Calendar. They explain the different locations and resources that can be reserved through Calendar like meeting rooms, projectors and computers.
episodes.title: Calendar Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate setting up a centralized contacting through the Contacts Service. They talk about concepts like CardDAV, DNS requirements, configuring Push notifications and the benefits of Contacts. They also show the viewer how to configure the client to connect to the Contacts Service.
episodes.title: Contacts Service

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate setting up a centralized messaging server through the Messages Service. They explain the protocols Jabber and Extensible Messaging and Presence that are used by the Messages Service. They talk about configuring the Messages Service to archive all messages as well as rebuilding the archive when recovery is needed.
episodes.title: Messages Service
